chapter.title: Architecture and API
chapter.subtitle: Discussion of &C2; internals
chapter.para: This chapter discusses some &C2; architecture assumptions, internals and more complex API use cases.

section.title: &C2; architecture overview
section.para: This section provides a very brief overview of &C2; architecture. If you would like us to cover some specific topic in more detail, please let us know on the mailing list.

section.title: Processing component pipeline
section.para: Processing in &C2; is based on a pipeline of processing components. The two main types of &C2; processing components are:

formalpara.title: Document Sources
formalpara.para: provide data for further processing. In a typical scenario, such a component would fetch search results from e.g. an external search engine, Lucene / Solr index or an XML file. Currently, &C2; distribution contains 12 different document source components.

formalpara.title: Clustering Algorithms
formalpara.para: organize documents provided by document sources into meaningful groups. Currently, two specialized clustering algorithms are available in &C2;: Lingo and STC. Additionally, a number of "synthetic" clustering algorithms are available, such as by URL clustering.

section.para: &C2; applications, such as &DCW; or &DCS; operate on a pipeline consisting of one document source and one clustering algorithm, but using &C2; Java API you can insert additional components at any point in the pipeline. Currently, the only component not falling into the above categories is a component for computing certain cluster quality metrics, but more components may be added in the future, e.g. for spell checking of user queries.

section.title: Processing component attributes
section.para: The behavior of both document sources and clustering algorithms depends on a number of attributes (settings) such as the number of documents to fetch or the number of clusters to produce. The way you provide attribute values for specific components depends on the &C2; application you are working with:

formalpara.title: &DCW;.
formalpara.para: In &DCW; you can provide attributes for document sources (such as number of results to fetch or preferred results language) before you issue a query in the Search view. Clustering algorithm attributes you can change using the sliders in the Attributes view.

formalpara.title: &DCS;.
formalpara.para: In &DCS;, you can provide attribute values as additional parameters in the POST request. Name of the POST parameter should be the identifier of the attribute you want to set (see for attribute identifiers). &C2; will attempt to convert the string value of the parameter to the required type (integer, float etc.).

section.para: For a complete reference of attributes of each &C2; component, please see .

section.title: &C2; XML data formats
section.para: This section shows examples of &C2; input and output XML formats, used consistently by all &C2; applications, including &DCW;, &DCS; and &WA;.

section.title: &C2; input XML format
section.para: To provide documents for &C2; clustering, use the following XML format:

figure.title: &C2; input XML format
figure.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <searchresult> <query>Globe</query> <document id="0"> <title>default</title> <url>http://www.globe.com.ph/</url> <snippet> Provides mobile communications (GSM) including GenTXT, handyphones, wireline services, an broadband Internet services. </snippet> </document> <document id="1"> <title>Skate Shoes by Globe | Time For Change</title> <url>http://www.globeshoes.com/</url> <snippet> Skaters, surfers, and showboarders designing in their own style. </snippet> </document>
...
</searchresult>

section.para: &C2; saves the clusters in the following XML format:
